Name:
unnamed (DE-89)
HMS Redmill (K554)
Fate:
Transferred to United Kingdom 30 November 1943
Sold for scrapping 30 January 1947[2] or 4 February 1947[3]

Constructive total loss after 27 April 1945[1]
Returned to United States 20 January 1947 [3]
Acquired:
Returned by United Kingdom 20 January 1947
30 November 1943
Namesake: Captain Robert Redmill (ca. 1765-1819), British naval officer who was commanding officer of HMS Polyphemus during the Battle of Trafalgar in 1805[4]
Propulsion:
Two Foster-Wheeler Express "D"-type water-tube boilers
GE 13,500 shp (10,070 kW) steam turbines and generators (9,200 kW)
Electric motors for 12,000 shp (8,900 kW)
Two shafts
Range: 5,500 nautical miles (10,200 km) at 15 knots (28 km/h)
processing systems:
SA & SL type radars
Type 144 series Asdic
MF Direction Finding antenna
HF Direction Finding Type FH 4 antenna
Armament:
3 × 3 in (76 mm) /50 Mk.22 guns
1 × twin Bofors 40 mm mount Mk.I
7–16 × 20 mm Oerlikon guns
Mark 10 Hedgehog antisubmarine mortar
Depth charges
QF 2-pounder naval gun
